content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: C'est une chose inédite que de travailler sur du morse. Bonne idée
In the first test you wait for 57 but your input is 057 in morse so there is a mistake. Unless you don't want zero at the beginning of your string so you have to explain it

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good for clash of code, not too difficult for JS

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It's easy for python users.
In my case, it was just testing a user if they know how to create a dictionary and if they know how to use strip()

I highly recommend NOT surrounding the numbers in the statement with an ASCII box, this will make it much easier to copy paste. Maybe use monospace instead.
Also for reverse mode it would be more appropriate to require that morse digits be separated by spaces, this is to make it more apparent how the sequences are delimited.
Thank you for your response! I will make the changes!
Yes, this is intentional, if you look at the code. But will write it in the statement. Thank you for your response

Good! That looks ideal now. Question: Is the leading zero necessary in test case 1? See: -----

It can be misleading in reverse mode. Maybe introduce the zero by itself as a first test case.

I'll also add some formatting and constraints to your statement.

Also note that 59741093046 in test case validator 3 cannot fit in an 32-bit integer.
It's especially vicious in that it's a validator. So all your local tests will work but you will never get 100% if, like me, you solve the puzzle by accumulating the digits into a 32-bit variable.

This issue concerns mostly lower-level languages but it is an important one. I've added a constraint to remediate it.

That said I recommend you make test case 3 a 64-bit number as well to ensure it fails if the user tries to fit it inside a 32-bit variable.
